awd_titl_txt: Conference: Collaborative Research on Risk, Energy Development, and Environmental Sustainability in the Navajo Nation
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a conference proposal that would convene scholars working on issues of environment, climate, and economy in the Navajo Nation, for a two-day conference to examine how methods in ethnographic, historical, spatial, hydro-geological, and indigenous research can improve our understandings of vulnerability and risk produced in contexts of sustained energy extraction. The workshop provides a platform for scientific collaboration and capacity building among a group historically underrepresented in science, through professional collaboration with scholars at a tribal college. The research collaborative that will emerge through this workshop has the potential to become a model for other Native Nations to build research capacity and development. The workshop will facilitate the development of more effective methodologies and avenues for the dissemination of findings from anthropological research to promote public understanding of science and the scientific process. The project also contributes to the training of graduate students in methods of scientifically-grounded and empirical data collection.  

The objective of the workshop is to develop a research agenda to advance knowledge of extractive contexts in which questions of environmental risk and local governance are at stake. The proposed activity advances new understandings of behavioral sciences with the potential to transform the way we understand technological and cultural change in times of energy and environmental crisis. Workshop participants will meet at Diné College in Tsaile, Arizona, in Navajo Nation to share research interests and discuss work in Diné political ecology and resource geographies. The objective of the workshop is to develop a long-term collaborative project. The project would advance anthropological science in the areas of environmental risk, extractive industry, and energy transitions. The workshop aims to build networks of indigenous political ecological scholarship in theorizing the relationship between technological and cultural change, and energy transitions. Results will improve theoretical understanding of the material and economic conditions of indigenous environmental governance in the 21st century and establish a basis for future comparative research in understanding how other extractive contexts, particularly within Native Nations in the United States (e.g., Crow, Hopi, MHA Nation, Northern Cheyenne) might theorize and implement strategies for economic and energy transitions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this NSF Workshop Project were to curate meaningful, sustained, critical dialogue on the science, governance, technology, and meaning of toxicity and transition in the Navajo Nation, by carefully inviting leading Diné knowledge-makers and experts in this field for a series of deliberative dialogues wherein the researcher/researched relationship was up-ended by creating a space for co-analysis and decolonial thinking.

Due to COVID-19's dire impacts on the Navajo Nation and impacts on all Workshop participants' travel, we shifted this Workshop to an online format. In doing so, we in fact curated more intimate focus groups across four virtual sessions from December 2020 until July 2021. Each session involved seven expert participants for a total of ~30 total participants (with some repeat invitations); all (other than PI Dana Powell) were citizens of the Navajo Nation. All participants across all four workshops were deeply experienced in one of the following: science, advocacy, politics, governance, and scholarship of energy and environmental issues in the Navajo Nation. Each workshop was organized thematically around a set of generative prompts, then allowed to take shape through a semi-structured focus group process, where we spoke with one another as knowledge co-producers and colleagues. Each workshop lasted 3-4 hours, for a total of ~16 recorded hours of engagement. This emphasis represents a commitment within the project to decolonial methodologies, that is in this case, to move away from the "expert" versus "interlocutor" (or "subject" and "object" of research) relationship, to a different mode of co-analysis as equals, wherein all participants are both generators of research questions and respondents to those questions. We thus accomplished the preliminary stages of methodological innovation, by experimenting with decolonial research practices through this series of deliberative discussions on core themes, including: regenerative economies, sovereignty, transition, toxicity/contamination, and science/indigenous knowledge. We accomplished an identification of core thematics and a new lexicon for understanding environmental change and environmental justice in the Navajo Nation and are now ready to deploy this new lexicon and co-analysis method into a longer term collaborative research project. This Workshop series accomplished the construction of a novel archive: we now have complete transcriptions (including Diné language-to-English translation) of all four events, documenting the emergent process of co-analysis around shared matters of concern, to help advance a critical, Diné-centered method for research justice. 

Objectives:

  • To curate and facilitate four listening sessions about the status of environmental research and knowledge among a select group scholars, policymakers, and practitioners within the Navajo Nation. 

  • To establish a community of practice or advisory working group of Diné intellectuals and leaders in sustainability, toxicity, and transition to guide collaborative research in the future. 

  • To create an archive of digital and transcript material to inform future publications and research programs for members of the team.

Results:

(a) a new community of practice among Diné knowledge-makers (scientists, advocates, policymakers, scholars, allies) to address emerging environmental and economic challenges facing the Navajo Nation and other Indigenous Nations with extensive natural resources; (b) an unprecedented archive (16+ hours of recordings and complete transcripts) of this expert deliberation, co-analysis, and critical reflection for theoretical and methodological innovation in a future phase of the collaboration; (c) a tighter and sustained collaboration among existing academic colleagues Co-PIs Dana Powell and Andrew Curley, and also Teresa Montoya (Univ of Chicago, Anthropology), with our extended network of experts outside of academia, who are engaged in knowledge production and analysis of energy/environmental/economics in Navajo Nation as pertaining to energy infrastructures and their impacts on sovereignty and flourishing livelihoods. 

  • Our Workshop achieved a preliminary re-articulation of the problems and opportunities for sustainability research, broader education, and collaboration with tribal government and NGO partners, for future research on toxicity, transition, and sustainability in the Navajo Nation. It also offered Powell a platform for comparative dialogues on similar issues in Indigenous communities in Taiwan and offers to create a point of knowledge exchange and elaboration through a comparative discussion on these core issues, between Diné peoples and Austronesian peoples in Taiwan (where Powell has been located for much of this virtual workshop period). Another achievement is the engagement of the University of Arizona in this project, given Andrew Curley's change of institutions during the course of the Award. Our partnership with Teresa Montoya extends our institutional collaborations to U-Chicago. 

  • The project allowed for the engagement of one Diné undergraduate and one Diné graduate student to serve for the first time as Research Assistants on a long-term research endeavor. Additionally, the project strengthened the informal networks of Diné environmental researchers and intellectuals on future directions for tribal policymaking and professional development. 

  • The project also allowed for Powell as PI to support the successful submission of an NSF Research Experience for Graduates proposal 

  • We are currently in the process of designing a dissemination plan, to return transcripts to participants
